title: Structural Studies of Pilus Biogenesis and Bacterial Adhesion
abstractText:
We propose here to study the structures of proteins 
involved in the pathogenesis caused by uropathogenic 
Escherichia coli. Urinary tract infections are the 
second most common infections after infections of the 
respiratory tract. The infectious process requires 
adhesive hair-like fibres termed pili . Pili serve 
as attachment devices which allow targeting of the 
bacteria to specific host tissues. A pilus is made of 
a large number of protein subunits which polymerise 
together to form a fibre. At the tip of the pilus, 
there is a sugar-binding protein (or adhesin ) which 
specifically recognises receptors displayed at the 
surface of the host tissue. In this proposal, we plan 
to obtain snapshots of the molecular interactions 
required to assemble pili, and those required by the 
adhesin to recognise its cognate receptor. The planned
 research program outlined here will not only 
contribute to our understanding of pathogenicity 
leading to urinary tract infections but will also 
contribute to our understanding of diseases caused 
by other bacteria that utilize very similar mechanism 
to assemble pili and to recognise their receptor. 
Such bacteria include Haemophilus influenzae 
(causing ottitis media, or meningitis) or Salmonella 
typhimurium (causing gastroenteritis): any insight 
acquired on the uropathogenic E. coli system will 
benefit investigations of a wide range of pathogens. 
Structural studies will also help design new 
antibiotic drugs which will target either pilus 
assembly or bacterial adhesion.
